content.text: Node.js Raspberry Pi - GPIO Introduction
What is GPIO?
GPIO stands for General Purpose Input Output.
content.html: GPIO stands for General Purpose Input Output.

content.text: The Raspberry Pi has two rows of GPIO pins, which are connections between the Raspberry Pi, and the real world.
content.html: The Raspberry Pi has two rows of GPIO pins, which are connections between the Raspberry Pi, and the real world.

content.text: Output pins are like switches that the Raspberry Pi can turn on or off (like turning on/off a LED light). But it can also send a signal to another device.
content.html: Output pins are like switches that the Raspberry Pi can turn on or off (like turning on/off a LED light). But it can also send a signal to another device.

content.text: Input pins are like switches that you can turn on or off from the outside world (like a on/off light switch). But it can also be a data from a sensor, or a signal from another device.
content.html: Input pins are like switches that you can turn on or off from the outside world (like a on/off light switch). But it can also be a data from a sensor, or a signal from another device.

content.text: That means that you can interact with the real world, and control devices and electronics using the Raspberry PI and its GPIO pins!

Taking a Closer Look at the Breadboard

A breadboard is used for prototyping electronics, it allows you to create circuits without soldering. It is basically a plastic board, with a grid of tie-points (holes). Inside the board there are metal strips connecting the different tie-points in specific ways.

Install the onoff Module
To interface with the GPIO on the Raspberry Pi using Node.js, we will use a Module called "onoff".

content.text: Install the onoff module using npm:
